boat.name: Frolic
boat.place_built: Hegartys Yard Oldcourt Skibereen West Cork Ireland
boat.full_description:
Frolic is a traditional gaff cutter, built in 2005 at Hegartys Yard in west Cork Ireland.

She is an Ed Burnett design and can be seen 'in build' along with her plans and sail detail by visiting Ed's website and look for design number 110. She has larch planking on steamed oak frames, teak decks, copper nails and silicon bronze keel bolts with a 1.2 tonne lead keel. The little Faversham solid fuel stove and Colin Freake blocks everywhere complete the journey back in time. She is powered by a fine Beta Marine 20hp engine. 

Ivan Godley bought her from her previous owner of seven years, Cormac Levis, the traditional boat historian and author of the book 'Towelsail Yawls' which is a history of the traditional lobster boats of west Cork and a cracking good read! If you can get a copy on Amazon, it's a worthwhile buy.

After buying Frolic in October 2013 she spent the winter in Whoolies Yard, west Cork where she had a refit.

She was re-launched  on 7 April 2014 and sailed the 140 miles home to Fenit, north Kerry. A brave little boat she faced the southwest coast of Ireland swells without a bother, even when handled by a mostly hungover crew.
boat.construction_details: Larch planking on steamed oak ribs. Teak deck. Copper nails, silicon bronze bolts, lead keel.
boat.short_description: Frolic is a traditional gaff cutter, kept in Fenit, North Kerry.
